Abstract Abstract
This specification defines how an Atom Publishing Protocol collection This specification defines how an Atom Publishing Protocol collection
may process multipart/related requests and also defines how a service may process multipart/related requests and also defines how a service
announces that it accepts multipart/related entities. announces that it accepts multipart/related entities.

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
The Atom Publishing Protocol [RFC5023] defines Media Collections and The Atom Publishing Protocol [RFC5023] defines Media Collections and
how to create a Media Resource by POSTing the media to the Media how to create a Media Resource by POSTing the media to the Media
Collection. RFC 5023 does not define handling multipart/related Collection. RFC 5023 does not define handling multipart/related
[RFC2387] representations nor does it specify how the acceptance of [RFC2387] representations nor does it specify how the acceptance of
such representations should be advertised in the Service Document. such representations should be advertised in the Service Document.
This specification covers both the processing and the Service This specification covers both the processing and the Service
Document aspects of handling multipart/related content. Document aspects of handling multipart/related content.

There may be other specifications that define uses for multipart There may be other specifications that define uses for multipart
representations in the AtomPub context; this specification only representations in the AtomPub context; this specification only
describes one particular representation and how to use it in the describes one particular representation and how to use it in the
media-resource creation process. Follow-on multipart/related media-resource creation process. Follow-on multipart/related
specifications will have to define a method by which a server can specifications will have to define a method by which a server can
differentiate which specification is in force, which is beyond the differentiate which specification is in force, which is beyond the
scope of this document. scope of this document.
A multipart/related POST to a Media Collection MUST be a valid A multipart/related POST to a Media Collection MUST be a valid
multipart/related representation as defined by [RFC2387] and MUST multipart/related representation as defined by [RFC2387] and MUST
contain two body parts. One, referred to as the Media Part, MUST be contain two body parts. One, referred to as the Entry Part, MUST be
an Atom Entry with a media type of 'application/atom+xml' or an Atom Entry with a media type of 'application/atom+xml' or
'application/atom+xml;type=entry'. The other, referred to as the 'application/atom+xml;type=entry'. The other, referred to as the
Media Part, MUST be of a media type acceptable to the collection. Media Part, MUST be of a media type acceptable to the collection.
The object root MUST be the Entry Part. The Entry Part's atom: The object root MUST be the Entry Part. The Entry Part's atom:
content element MUST have a 'src' attribute whose value is the URI of content element MUST have a 'src' attribute whose value is the URI of
the related media in the Media Part. The 'src' attribute value MUST the related media in the Media Part. The 'src' attribute value MUST
be a 'cid:' URI as defined by [RFC2392]. The Content-Type: header of be a 'cid:' URI as defined by [RFC2392]. The Content-Type: header of
the POST request MUST specify "application/atom+xml;type=entry" or the POST request MUST specify "application/atom+xml;type=entry" or
"application/atom+xml". "application/atom+xml".
skipping to change at page 5, line 12 skipping to change at page 5, line 12
While a multipart/related request replaces three round trips in the While a multipart/related request replaces three round trips in the
typical Media Resource creation scenario, AtomPub has no mechanism to typical Media Resource creation scenario, AtomPub has no mechanism to
report partial success. Thus, the handling of a multipart/related report partial success. Thus, the handling of a multipart/related
request by the server MUST be atomic; that is, either succeed with a request by the server MUST be atomic; that is, either succeed with a
201 Created status code, or return an error status code. 201 Created status code, or return an error status code.
5. Service Document Extension 5. Service Document Extension
An AtomPub service announces that it will accept multipart/related An AtomPub service announces that it will accept multipart/related
POSTs by an extension to the app:accept element. The "alternate" POSTs by an extension to the app:accept element. The "alternate"
attribute's value MUST be one more more tokens, space-separated if attribute's value MUST be one or more tokens, space-separated if more
more than one. The only token defined by this specification is than one. The only token defined by this specification is
"multipart-related". The presence of the "multipart-related" token "multipart-related". The presence of the "multipart-related" token
in the 'alternate' attribute's value indicates that the collection in the 'alternate' attribute's value indicates that the collection
accepts multipart/related POSTs whose Media Part has a content-type accepts multipart/related POSTs whose Media Part has a content-type
matching that specified in the app:accept element. The following matching that specified in the app:accept element. The following
example indicates a collection that allows the creation of resources example indicates a collection that allows the creation of resources
with the Ogg Bitstream Format and will also accept them in multipart with the Ogg Bitstream Format and will also accept them in multipart
form. form.
<app:accept alternate="multipart-related">application/ogg</app:accept> <app:accept alternate="multipart-related">application/ogg</app:accept>
The 'multipart' attribute is foreign markup and will be ignored by The 'alternate' attribute is foreign markup and will be ignored by
clients that do not understand multipart/related uploads. In clients that do not understand multipart/related uploads. In
addition it permits the full range of the app:accept element to be addition it permits the full range of the app:accept element to be
used. The following indicates that the collection accepts any image used. The following indicates that the collection accepts any image
media type and will also accept them in multipart form. media type and will also accept them in multipart form.
<app:accept alternate="multipart-related">image/*</app:accept> <app:accept alternate="multipart-related">image/*</app:accept>
The 'alternate' attribute allows clients that are unaware of The 'alternate' attribute allows clients that are unaware of
multipart/related to continue to operate as normal since the multipart/related to continue to operate as normal since the
alternate attribute is foreign markup. The alternative, which is to alternate attribute is foreign markup. The alternative, which is to
put a multipart/related media type in the app:accept element, loses put a multipart/related media type in the app:accept element, loses
flexibility since the 'type' parameter to the multipart/related media flexibility since the 'type' parameter to the multipart/related media
type accepts only media types and not media ranges. type accepts only media types and not media ranges.
6. Examples 6. Examples
Here is an example service document that contains two media Here is an example service document that contains two media
collections. The first collection accepts multipart/related POSTs collections. The first collection accepts multipart/related POSTs
for video media types only. The second collection accepts multipart/ for video media types only. It does not accept multipart/related
related POSTs for image/jpeg and image/png media types. POSTs for audio or text. The second collection accepts multipart/
related POSTs for image/gif and image/png media types.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding='utf-8'?> <?xml version="1.0" encoding='utf-8'?>
<service xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2007/app" <service xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2007/app"
xmlns:atom="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> xmlns:atom="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom">
<workspace> <workspace>
<atom:title>Media Collections</atom:title> <atom:title>Media Collections</atom:title>
<collection <collection
href="http://example.org/blog/main" > href="http://example.org/blog/main" >
<atom:title>Mostly Media</atom:title> <atom:title>Mostly Media</atom:title>
<accept alternate="multipart-related">video/*</accept> <accept alternate="multipart-related">video/*</accept>

</workspace> </workspace>
</service> </service>
Here is an example interaction of a client creating a new Media Here is an example interaction of a client creating a new Media
Resource in the Pictures Only media collection using a png image in a Resource in the Pictures Only media collection using a png image in a
multipart/related representation. multipart/related representation.

content-type: multipart/related; Content-Type: multipart/related;

The initial request does not have to have the Entry Part first to
indicate that it is the object root, it's location can be indicated
by the 'start' attribute, as in this example.
POST /blog/pic HTTP/1.1
Host: example.org
Content-Length: nnnn
Content-Type: multipart/related;
boundary="===============1605871705==";
type="application/atom+xml";
start="<10101033@example.com>"
Slug: The Beach
MIME-Version: 1.0
Media Post
--===============1605871705==
Content-Type: image/gif
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-ID: <99334422@example.com>
GIF89a...binary image data...
--===============1605871705==
Content-Type: application/atom+xml; charset="utf-8"
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-ID: <10101033@example.com>
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<entry xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom">
<title>The Beach</title>
<id>urn:uuid:1225c695-cfb8-4ebb-aaaa-80da344efa6a</id>
<updated>2005-10-07T17:17:08Z</updated>
<author><name>Daffy</name></author>
<summary type="text">
A nice sunset picture over the water.
</summary>
<content src="cid:99334422@example.com"
type="image/gif" />
</entry>
